Dear Ms. Haas:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10177 Resident restraint
Section (1) The facility shall establish and follow written policy and
Description procedures specifying the use of resident restraint.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 05/09/2025 Youth A was improperly restrained and sustained
injuries as a result.
Investigation The complainant was interviewed over the phone on 05/19/2025
and had no additional information to offer.
Staff 1 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
05/20/2025. Staff 1 recalled being elsewhere in the facility when
he saw the incident involving Youth A beginning. Youth A was
already being restrained on the ground when he was able to come
provide assistance. Staff 1 saw Youth A be released from the first
restraint, only to then get up and hit Staff 6 in the face. Staff 1
assisted after the second restraint and when the mechanical
restraints were placed on Youth A. Staff 1 assisted with
transporting Youth A to her room. He recalled this being done by
rolling her on to her mattress and slowly pulling the mattress
inside of her room. Youth A was picked up by other staff and
placed on her bed while still in the mechanical restraints. Staff 1
and Supervisor 1 sat next to Youth A and restrained her arms as
this occurred because Youth A was beginning to escalate
again. While Youth A was physically struggling and verbally
aggressive, Staff 1 recalled Youth A stating her handcuffs were on
too tight. Staff 1 recalled training on how to ensure this was not
the case, and every time he checked the handcuffs they were not
placed on too tightly. He also recalled Youth A trying to pull her
hands out of the handcuffs. Youth A continuously stated that if the
mechanical restraints were removed, she would assault
staff. Staff 1 recalled Youth A laying on her bed at one point, and
he and Supervisor 1 were able to let go of her. This was when
Youth A threw up on the floor. Staff 1 tried to keep Youth A’s hair
out of the vomit and she commented that he needed to let go of
her and she didn’t care about her hair. Staff 1 believed that it took
2

20 or 30 minutes for he and Supervisor 1 to feel comfortable
taking off the mechanical restraints. Youth A was continuing to
make comments about assaulting staff but had began to do so
with less energy. Staff 1 recalled exiting the room and after the
door closed, Youth A began to yell and hit it. Staff 1 did not recall
seeing any visible marks or bruises to Youth A, and he did not
believe she had any vomit on her by the time they left the
room. He recalled some redness to Youth A’s nose, and he
believed this was caused by her slamming her own head on the
ground during the first part of the restraint.
Staff 2 was interviewed on 05/20/2025 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He
recalled being involved in the restraint of Youth A from the
beginning of the incident. Youth A began to get upset with Staff 2
and Staff 6 after she lost points through the facility’s behavioral
management program. Youth A began to kick and hit the unit
door, and then began to attempt to make an outgoing phone
call. Staff 2 recalled attempting to verbally redirect Youth A. As
she would make the outgoing phone call, Staff 6 stood nearby and
hung up the phone each time Youth A attempted to do so and
explained to her why she could not make a phone call at that
time. This occurred several times. Youth A began to get
physically assaultive with Staff 6. Staff 2 and Staff 6
communicated that they were going to attempt to restraint Youth A
at that time. Staff 2 and Staff 6 took a hold of one of Youth A’s
arms and attempted a standing restraint of Youth A. As this
occurred, Staff 2 recalled seeing Supervisor 1 and Supervisor 2
come in. As the standing restraint occurred Youth A began to
fight back against Staff 2. Staff 2 recalled Youth A dropping her
weight and going to the ground. Youth A was then laying in a
prone position on her stomach, and Staff 2 and Staff 6 both
attempted to continue to restrain her because she had continued
to be verbally and physically aggressive. Staff 2 described this as
Youth A squirming, kicking, biting and spitting. Staff 2 recalled
someone, he could not remember which specific staff, attempting
to restrain Youth A’s legs as well. Eventually Staff 2 switched out
and moved to try to contain Youth A’s legs. Staff 2 reported never
making contact with Youth A’s neck or head at any point during
the restraint. He saw Youth A attempting to hit her own head on
the carpet as the restraint was occurring. Staff 2 recalled Youth A
calming down enough to have the restraint end, but then Youth A
proceeded to get up quickly and hit Staff 6. Another restraint
occurred. Staff 2 stated mechanical restraints had to be used in
order to help de-escalate Youth A. Staff 2 believed it was
supervisors who then decided to use a mattress from Youth A’s
3

room to help move her to her room. As this was getting set up
Staff 2 recalled seeing Supervisor 2 rubbing Youth A’s back in
attempt to calm her, but Youth A did not respond in kind. Staff 2
reminded Youth A that she still had the ability to have the
handcuffs removed and go to her room on her own, but she only
responded with continued verbal aggression. Staff 2 recalled
Youth A being placed gently on the mattress and then being slid to
her room. When Youth A was in her bedroom she was sat up and
staff were continuing to try to verbally deescalate her with no
success. When she sat up Youth A continued to try to kick and
spit at any staff near her. Staff 2 recalled telling her that he was
going to try to restrain her legs to prevent injuring herself or
anyone else. Eventually staff were able to remove the handcuffs
and attempt to leave the room quickly. After her door was shut
Youth A kicked and pounded on the door, threatening and
swearing towards staff. Staff 2 stated he never saw any staff
place any of their weight on Youth A’s back or neck, or do
anything that would have affected Youth A’s breathing. Staff 2
believed Youth A was verbally aggressive and threatening for a
majority of the incident. Staff 2 saw some injuries to Youth A,
specifically “carpet burn” on her nose and possibly a little bit of
blood. Staff 2 confirmed seeing Youth A vomit twice during the
restraint incident. The first time occurred after the initiation of the
restraint while out in the unit. Staff 2 believed this occurred
because Youth A was significantly verbally escalated. The vomit
occurred on the counter near the phone, and Youth A went to the
ground shortly thereafter. Staff 2 denied ever seeing any vomit on
Youth A at that time. The second occurrence was when Youth A
was in her room. Staff 2 recalled seeing a small amount of vomit
on the floor in front of Youth A’s toilet. Staff 2 did not see any
vomit on Youth A at that time as well. Staff 2 recalled bringing
Youth A some cleaning supplies about an hour or so later, when
she had calmed down enough that he felt safe opening the
doorway. Youth A was able to clean her room at that time. Staff 2
also recalled working the following morning. Youth A slept in and
he did not have much contact with her other than performing eyes
on checks.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed on 05/20/2025 with DHHS Worker
1 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He
recalled involving himself in the incident when Youth A made
physical contact with staff. As he came in the unit Staff 2 and
Staff 6 were attempting to restrain Youth A. He recalled
witnessing them using the MACH 2 standing hold with Youth
A. He believed Youth A “dead-legged” and fell to the
ground. Supervisor 1 recalled seeing Staff 2 and Staff 6 attempt a
4

ground hold of Youth A at that time. Youth A was on her stomach,
but commented staff were trained in this restraint hold. Supervisor
1 did not believe anyone had any weight on Youth A’s chest or
back. Supervisor 1 attempted to help with the restraint while
Youth A was on the ground. As he did, he recalled Youth A
kicking, screaming and attempting to pull her hands
free. Supervisor 1 believed Youth A had free movement of her
head and neck. He referred to seeing her spit and attempt to bite
staff during the restraint, as well as slamming her head on the
ground. He recalled seeing Supervisor 2 offer a blanket to help
Youth A not gain any injuries to her face or head. At some point
during the restraint, Supervisor 1 left and performed room checks
of other youth. He then went to the control room to continue to
monitor the situation. Supervisor 1 recalled coming back in the
room to continue to assist when the restraint had ended. At that
point Youth A was still laying on the ground. Supervisor 1 recalled
Youth A asking for a drink of water, and when a cup was offered
to her, she slapped it away. Not long after Youth A got up, she hit
Staff 6. Supervisor 1 and Staff 1 initiated another
restraint. Supervisor 1 recalled this restraint moving to the ground
in a similar manner to the first restraint. He could not recall how
long it took, but Supervisor 1 confirmed mechanical restraints
were used on Youth A because of her continued fighting back for
an extended period of time. Youth A was transported to her room
on her bedroom mattress, laying on it while in
handcuffs. Supervisor 1 recalled Youth A pausing her aggressive
behavior as this occurred. When she was sat up in her room, she
began to kick and scream at himself and Staff 1 again. Supervisor
1 performed a sitting MACH 2 restraint with Staff 1. Youth A
continued to attempt to headbutt and kick at Supervisor 1 and
Staff 1. Supervisor 1 reported moving Youth A to a prone position
on her bed slab as she rolled herself over from a sitting
position. Supervisor 1 believed the restraint holds were
successful and did not require much force despite Youth A’s
consistent fighting back. As Youth A continued to headbutt, spit
and bite at himself and Staff 1. Supervisor 1 noticed she vomited a
small amount on the floor near her bed. He recalled telling her
that they would “scooch” her away from it, and he did not notice
any on her face. Supervisor 1 recalled not being concerned about
her breathing at that point because she continued to yell at
them. Supervisor 1 believed it took about another 30 minutes for
Youth A to cease fighting and threatening staff. Supervisor 1 went
to remove the handcuffs after explaining to Youth A what they
were going to do. As this occurred, Youth A began to resist and
fight back. Supervisor 1 decide to remove the mechanical
restraints because of the length of time the entire situation had
5

occurred. As Staff 1 came out of the room to leave Youth A in
alone, she charged at the door. Supervisor 1 recalled the door
closed before it created a safety issue with Youth A running
toward it. Youth A began to kick at the door and scream at
staff. Supervisor 1 recalled Staff 2 came back some time later
with cleaning supplies for Youth A to clean her room. Supervisor
1 also worked the next morning and noted Youth A slept in well
past the morning. Supervisor 1 recalled seeing small abrasions
on Youth A’s nose, which he attributed to her slamming her head
on the carpet during the restraint. Youth A did not comment on
any injuries or pain.
Staff 3 was interviewed on 05/20/2025 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He was
outside with a different unit when the incident began. He took the
other unit inside to their separate unit and ensured staff coverage
so that he could assist with Youth A. He saw other Staff 6
speaking with Youth A, who was visibly upset. He saw Staff 2 and
Staff 6 initiate a restraint. He entered the unit to assist. As he
approached, he saw Youth A go to the ground and Staff 2 and
Staff 6 follow her and restrain her on the ground. Youth A
attempted to kick, bite and spit at staff, and was verbally
aggressive and threatening. Staff 3 attempted to secure Youth
A’s legs as she kicked. Staff 3 recalled Staff 4 attempted to use
blankets to help limit Youth A’s ability to hit her own head on the
floor. He reported Supervisor 2 provided coaching and support
during the situation. Staff 3 released Youth A from the
restraint. As this occurred, Supervisor 2 got Youth A a glass of
water she requested. Youth A slapped the water away and got
up. Youth A immediately hit Staff 6. Staff 3 attempted to restrain
Youth A again with Supervisor 1. Youth A dropped her weight and
went to the ground, laying in a prone position. Staff 3 recalled this
restraint took a long time. Staff 3 was spit on multiple times by
Youth A. Youth A was eventually placed in shackles because of
her continued fighting and threats to staff. She was transported to
her room on a mattress. Staff 3 believed he saw spit or vomit that
came from Youth A during the restraint but denied that it was ever
on her face or that her face was near where it was located. Staff 3
denied himself or any other staff ever having any contact with
Youth A’s head or neck during any part of the restraint. He did not
believe anyone had their weight on Youth A’s back or that her
breathing was restricted in any way.
Staff 4 was interviewed on 05/20/2025 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She
recalled seeing the incident begin while watching from the control
6

room. Staff 4 came to the situation as Staff 2, Staff 3 and Staff 6
were attempting to restraint Youth A. She took responsibility for
clearing Youth A’s room ahead of a possible room
confinement. She attempted to help with the restraint by holding
Youth A’s legs. Youth A had dropped her weight and was in a
prone position on the floor. Staff 4 did not recall seeing anyone
place their weight on Youth A in any way that would have caused
bruising or restricted her breathing. She saw Youth A hit her head
on the carpet on her own accord several times during the
restraint. Youth A was continuously verbally aggressive during
the restraint. Staff 4 was able to release Youth A’s legs and Staff
2, Staff 3 and Supervisor 2 ended the floor restraint, only for Youth
A to get up and hit Staff 6 in the face. Staff 4 did not participate in
the next restraint after this occurred but was still present in the
situation. She recalled Youth A hitting her head on the carpet and
Supervisor 2 provided a blanket to help protect Youth A’s
head. Staff 4 recalled hearing Youth A state that she couldn’t
breathe with the blanket under her head, so it was
removed. When Youth A was moved to her bedroom, Staff 4 took
on other tasks while other staff still worked with Youth A. Staff 4
reiterated she never saw other staff in a position that would have
caused bruising or restrictions to Youth A’s breathing, but noted
Youth A was consistently fighting back against the staff’s
holds. Staff 4 recalled seeing Youth A spit blood at one point, and
she believed this occurred from Youth A’s aggressive head
movements while on the ground. Staff 4 did not see Youth A
vomit at any point, but noted in past incidents Youth A became
verbally escalated to the point of stressing her body.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed on 05/20/2025 with DHHS Worker
1 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She
recalled hearing screaming from Youth A from inside the unit,
including her demanding to speak with a supervisor. Supervisor 2
intentionally did not enter because she did not want to step on the
toes of the staff that were already trying to reason with and
verbally de-escalate Youth A. When Youth A began to get
physically assaultive towards Staff 2 and Staff 6 involved,
Supervisor 2 came in the unit. She saw Staff 2 and Staff 6
attempt a standing restraint and escort of Youth A to her room
when Youth A “dead legged” and dropped to the ground. While
Staff 2, Staff 3 and Staff 6 involved restrained Youth A on the
ground, Supervisor 2 stood by and provided coaching and
direction to the staff. She saw Youth A struggling and fighting
back against staff. Supervisor 2 grabbed handcuffs and leg
shackles in case they would be needed because the restraint
attempts were not successful. Supervisor 2 saw Staff 4
7

attempting to assist Youth A in preventing her from hitting her own
head on the floor. Supervisor 2 eventually took over for Staff
4. Eventually Youth A was calm where Supervisor 2 instructed
staff to slowly release her. When the restraint was ended Youth A
stayed on the floor, and began to verbally escalate again. She
was making demands, including asking for water. When water
was provided to her, Youth A slapped it away. Supervisor 2
stated she checked on the other youth in the unit when Staff 6
was hit in the face by Youth A. She was not directly involved in
the 2nd restraint that was initiated on the ground. Supervisor 2
decided the use of mechanical restraints was necessary. These
were applied and it took time for Youth A to calm
down. Supervisor 2 recalled swapping out of the restraint to
attend to Staff 6, who was injured from the hit by Youth A and had
to go to the hospital. Supervisor 2 recalled coming back to the
facility and Youth A was in a room confinement. Youth A was still
escalated. Supervisor 2 saw a small amount of vomit on the floor
of Youth A’s room. She did not believe this was harming Youth A
and did not believe there was any vomit on Youth A’s
person. Supervisor 2 believed that the restraint attempts were
performed as close to what is trained as possible considering
Youth A’s escalated state. She denied nor did she see any staff
have their weight on Youth A that would have caused any injury or
bruising.
Staff 5 was interviewed on 05/20/2025 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. Staff 5
was not involved in the restraints themselves, but spoke with
Youth A following the incident. Youth A was still escalated. Staff
5 saw vomit on the floor between Youth A’s bed and toilet. She
denied seeing any on Youth A’s face or clothes. Staff 5
communicated the vomit could be cleaned up as soon as Youth A
was able to de-escalate to the point that staff felt safe opening her
door. Staff 5 did not see any noticeable bruising on Youth A,
other than some redness on her face. Staff 5 did not hear Youth
A remark on any pain or injuries. Staff 5 confirmed she assisted
Youth A in showering either the day after the incident or the
following day. When Youth A took that shower there were no
behavioral concerns and Youth A did not comment on the restraint
incident at all.
Staff 6 was interviewed on 05/20/2025 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. Staff 6
reported she was involved in the incident from the start. Youth A
was upset because she wasn’t allowed a pencil due to earlier
behavioral and safety concerns. Youth A began to verbally
8

escalate, directing that specifically at Staff 6. Youth A was
directed to go to her room, which she briefly did willingly only to
then go to the doors of the unit and begin kicking and
screaming. Staff 6 attempted to verbally de-escalate Youth A with
no success. She recalled Youth A throwing a chair at one of the
doors. Youth A attempted to make outgoing phone calls. Staff 6
explained that could not occur because of her behavior, but Youth
A did not stop. As Youth A continued to try to call out, Staff 6
reached over and hung up the phone. Youth A began to get more
physical and escalate verbally. Youth A was physically assaultive,
so Staff 6 felt it was necessary to attempt to restrain her. Staff 6
and Staff 2 attempted to implement a standing restraint of Youth
A. Staff 6 believed Staff 2 was not fully trained in the restraint
model at that time, but believed he did the best he could. When
the restraint was initiated, Youth A was bent over at the waist
slightly over the countertop. Staff 6 could not recall if Youth A
vomited. She recalled past incidents where Youth A was so
escalated from screaming that she would have small amounts of
vomit come up. Youth A began to fight back immediately and
quickly dropped her weight to the ground. Staff 6 attempted to
have Youth A lay comfortably on her stomach while still controlling
her arms from hitting back. Staff 6 recalled Youth A kicking, trying
to pull her arms away and attempting to grab Staff 6’s keys. She
recalled Youth A continuing to verbally escalate, including yelling
that staff should not let her go because she was going to get up
and hit them. Staff 6 saw Youth A hitting her head on the carpet
repeatedly. Youth A was tried to bite anyone who came near her
head. Staff 6 denied ever seeing any staff put their weight on
Youth A’s back or neck or do anything that could have restricted
her breathing. Staff 6 recalled trying to rub Youth A’s back in an
attempt to help calm her and Youth A yelled back to “stop
touching by fucking back.” Supervisor 2 instructed staff to end the
restraint because Youth A had calmed down. As all the staff
stood up, Youth A remained laying on the ground. She then began
to verbally escalate again. Youth A suddenly stood up and hit
Staff 6 in the face. Staff 6 stated she did not expect this and it
happened quickly enough that she could not brace herself. She
stumbled backward and lost her glasses. Staff 6 recalled
regaining her bearings and saw Youth A being restrained on the
ground. Staff 6 recalled Supervisor 1 asking her to leave the
unit. Staff 6 left the unit and eventually went to the hospital. She
did not see how the incident resolved itself nor worked with Youth
A in the following days.
Staff 7 was interviewed on 05/20/2025 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He
9

recalled witnessing the incident from the control room for its
entirety. Staff 7 was able to see through the windows into the unit,
watch the incident on the facility security cameras as well as listen
through the communication system. He recalled a significant
amount of disobedience and verbal aggression from Youth
A. Staff 7 believed the restraint attempt could have occurred
earlier, but Staff 6 was trying a significant amount of verbal de-
escalation. He saw both restraints but could not see specific
holds or positions of staff. He felt like he could see Youth A
fighting back during most of the restraint attempts.
Youth B and Youth C were interviewed separately on 06/04/2025
with DHHS Worker 1 during an announced, face-to-face visit to
the facility. Both youth did not see much of the incident because
they followed facility rules and were in their rooms when it
occurred. They both had similar recollections of hearing a
significant amount of screaming, threatening and crying from
Youth A as it occurred.
Youth A was interviewed over the phone in the presence of her
mother on 06/23/2025. Youth A remembered initially getting upset
because Staff 6 had unfairly taken points away from her. She
remembered getting restrained initially but did not understand
why. Youth A felt like it came out of nowhere and no one
explained what was going to occur. Youth A recalled falling to the
ground and fighting back against staff. She could not recall
exactly which staff had their hands on her at this point. She felt
like the staff involved were putting their knees into her shoulders
to hold her down. Youth A denied that anyone touched her head
or neck. She told the staff involved she could not breathe during
parts of the restraint. A staff that she could not name responded
to her that the restraint could be ended if she got up and went to
her room. Youth A recalled the first part of the restraint ending,
and she got up to make a phone call. A staff member that she
could not recall tried to stop her, so Youth A slapped her. Youth A
stated being restrained again in a similar manner to the first
restraint. She confirmed she continued to fight back against this
restraint. Youth A recalled being transported to her room. She
remembered throwing up at some point and believed that this was
in her hair until after the incident ended. Youth A denied the vomit
in her room being cleaned up, then clarified that she was not able
to shower until Sunday morning after the late Friday evening
incident. Youth A denied that she decided not to shower on
Saturday and believed that she was not offered to shower.
10

License Designee and Supervisor 2 were interviewed during an
announced, face-to-face visit to the facility on 07/07/2025. As a
trainer for staff at the facility in the chosen restraint model,
Supervisor 2 clarified the holds staff used during the restraint.
Staff were trained on MACH holds 1 through 5, and in this incident
they attempted to use MACH 1 and MACH 2 holds. Supervisor 2
explained these holds could be used in a standing position with a
youth as well as in a position where the youth is laying prone on
the ground. She stated the difference between MACH 1 and
MACH 2 holds is the arm positioning of the youth and staff
involved. Supervisor 2 described MACH 2 hold as being initiated
by facing the opposite direction of the youth, as it is performed the
staff are standing on either side of the youth then are facing the
same direction. Supervisor 2 described MACH 4 hold as requiring
one staff holding one arm of the youth apiece while the youth is
laying prone on the ground. Supervisor 2 stated that the facility’s
use of mechanical restraints is not drawn from the MACH restraint
training, but performed per the facility’s polices & procedures.
Video reviewed:
• Security video footage dated 05/09/2025 beginning at 4:36
PM and ending at 6:03 PM was provided and
reviewed. Youth A could be seen sitting with Staff 6 at a
table and abruptly getting up and going over to her door,
kicking it while it was closed. She was able to kick the door
open and then entered her bedroom. Youth A came out of
her room and tossed her bed and bedding on to the floor.
Youth A could be seen talking (moving her mouth) and
gesturing towards Staff 6. After a few minutes of standing
at her doorway, Youth A went to the unit doors and began
kicking and pounding on them. Youth A began to touch the
phone and appeared to be attempting to make phone
call. Multiple attempts were made with Staff 6 standing
nearby, reaching over to hang up the phone each
time. Youth A slapped Staff 6’s hand away multiple
times. Staff 6 attempted to initiate a standing restraint of
Youth A. Youth A was seen bent over the counter they
were standing near as Staff 2 attempted to assist. Staff 3
and Staff 4 entered the unit to assist. Youth A appeared to
drop her weight and Staff 2, Staff 3 and Staff 6 were able to
still hold her up as she struggled against Staff 2, Staff 3 and
Staff 6. Youth A was lowered to the ground and ended in a
prone position. Staff 4 was seen sitting on the back of
Youth A’s legs while Staff 2 and Staff 3 attempted to hold
Youth A’s arms. Staff 3 could be seen holding Youth A’s
arms behind her back. Staff 6 could also be seen
11

attempting to help restrain but the camera angle did not
allow a full view of her. Youth A’s head was obscured from
this angle. Youth A moved from appearing to lay still to
then moving throughout the restraint. Staff 2 eventually
helped Staff 4 in restraining Youth A’s legs, while Staff 3
and Staff 6 continued to restrain Youth A’s arms behind her
back. Supervisor 1 and Supervisor 2 were present but not
engaged in the restraint. Supervisor 2 brought over a towel
and placed underneath Youth A’s head. The angle of the
footage obscured any view of Youth A banging her head on
the ground. Youth A could be seen attempting to move her
legs against Staff 2 and Staff 4’s attempts to restrain them.
Supervisor 2 took over attempting to restraint Youth A’s left
leg and Staff 4 moved away from the restraint. Staff 4 came
back and took over for Staff 2 attempting to restrain Youth
A’s right leg. Staff began to slowly disengage with Youth A.
Staff 4 first let go of Youth A’s right leg and moved away,
then Staff 3 released her right arm and standing away from
Youth A. Staff 6 could be seen releasing Youth A’s left arm
and stayed kneeling next to her without having any contact.
Supervisor 2 was then seen laying on the back of Youth A’s
legs and then standing up and walking away from Youth A.
The first restraint attempt ended after approximately eight
minutes. Youth A continued to lay on the ground in a prone
position and was seen moving her head
intermittently. Supervisor 2 and Staff 6 attempted to help
Youth A stand up by holding her right arm, but Youth A
appeared to refuse and did not move from the floor.
Supervisor 2 moved away from Youth A and Staff 6 was
seen standing next to her while Youth A continued to lay on

Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per youth and staff
interviewed, documentation reviewed, and video reviewed the
facility did not follow written policy and procedures regarding
resident restraint. Staff involved utilized methods of restraint and
escorting of Youth A that were not approved techniques per the
MACH restraint model as staff were seen using more staff than
required for both the standing and floor restraints, staff sitting and
lying on Youth A’s legs during the floor restraint and staff carrying
Youth A on a mattress while mechanically restrained.
Additionally, the facility’s written policy and procedures regarding
resident restraint lack clarity on what methods are being utilized
from MACH. Facility policy allows staff that are not trained in
MACH to physically intervene with youth, that can lead to unsafe
physical management of youth and is in direct conflict with Rule
400.10125.
The agency was in compliance with affording Youth A the
opportunity to clean her room and shower afterward the incident.
